documentation.text:
@dev |
      | what's next:
      |
      | addresses that only accept kyc input should be able to receive packages by the bridge that are only kyc'd across byfrost.
      | ultimate accountability chain could be difficult, though a hash map of critical ipfs resources of chain data could suffice.
      | this would be the same issue as data accountability by trying to leverage multiple chains for data sales as well.
      |
      |

@param _nativeBip32X_type The native Bip32X type of this network. Ethereum is 60, Shyft is 7341, etc.
 @dev Invoke the constructor for ShyftSafe, which sets the owner and nativeBip32X_type class variables

@dev Removes the owner (creator of this contract)'s control completely. Functions such as linking the registry & cachegraph (& shyftSafe's setBridge), and importantly initializing this as a byfrost contract, are triggered by the owner, and as such a setting phase and afterwards triggering this function could be seen as a completely appropriate workflow.

@dev overload function for doHoldSafe, used by this contract's superclass - Shyft Safe. exchanges a users general balance for their safeBalance.
@notice The Shyft Safe rules are: if you have it, and you're asked to hold it, remove it from your supply and place it into Safe's. also, if you transfer a balance and have an issue, you should revert. this revert case is unnecessary in this implementation as there are simple binary checks for balance availability.

@dev |
      | what's next:
      |
      | addresses that only accept kyc input should be able to receive packages by the bridge that are only kyc'd across byfrost.
      | ultimate accountability chain could be difficult, though a hash map of critical ipfs resources of chain data could suffice.
      | this would be the same issue as data accountability by trying to leverage multiple chains for data sales as well.
      |
      |

@param _nativeBip32X_type The native Bip32X type of this network. Ethereum is 60, Shyft is 7341, etc.
 @dev Invoke the constructor for ShyftSafe, which sets the owner and nativeBip32X_type class variables

@dev Removes the owner (creator of this contract)'s control completely. Functions such as linking the registry & cachegraph (& shyftSafe's setBridge), and importantly initializing this as a byfrost contract, are triggered by the owner, and as such a setting phase and afterwards triggering this function could be seen as a completely appropriate workflow.

@dev overload function for doHoldSafe, used by this contract's superclass - Shyft Safe. exchanges a users general balance for their safeBalance.
@notice The Shyft Safe rules are: if you have it, and you're asked to hold it, remove it from your supply and place it into Safe's. also, if you transfer a balance and have an issue, you should revert. this revert case is unnecessary in this implementation as there are simple binary checks for balance availability.

devdoc.details: |      | what's next:      |      | addresses that only accept kyc input should be able to receive packages by the bridge that are only kyc'd across byfrost.      | ultimate accountability chain could be difficult, though a hash map of critical ipfs resources of chain data could suffice.      | this would be the same issue as data accountability by trying to leverage multiple chains for data sales as well.      |      |

constructor.details: Invoke the constructor for ShyftSafe, which sets the owner and nativeBip32X_type class variables

params._nativeBip32X_type: The native Bip32X type of this network. Ethereum is 60, Shyft is 7341, etc.

kycSend(address,uint256,uint256,bool,boo.details: | Performs a "kyc send", which is an automatic search between addresses for counterparty relationships within Trust Channels (whos rules dictate accessibility for auditing/enforcement/jurisdiction/etc.). If there is a match, the designated amount of assets is sent to the recipient.      | As there are accessor methods to check whether or not the counterparty's cachegraph is "dirty", there is little need to pass a "true" unless the transaction is critical (eg. DeFi atomic flash wrap) and there is a chance that there will need to be a unification pass before the transaction can pass with full assurety.

params._amount: The amount of assets that will be sent.
params._bip32X_type: The bip32X type of the assets that will be sent. These are synthetic (wrapped) assets, based on atomic locking.
params._identifiedAddress: The public address for the recipient to send assets (tokens) to.
params._payForDirty: Whether the sender will pay the additional cost to unify a cachegraph's relationships (if not, it will not complete).
params._requiredConsentFromAllParties: Whether to match the routing algorithm on the "consented" layer which indicates 2 way buy in of counterparty's attestation(s)

returns.result: | 0 = not enough balance to send    | 1 = consent required    | 2 = transfer cannot be processed due to transfer rules    | 3 = successful transfer

removeOwner().details: Removes the owner (creator of this contract)'s control completely. Functions such as linking the registry & cachegraph (& shyftSafe's setBridge), and importantly initializing this as a byfrost contract, are triggered by the owner, and as such a setting phase and afterwards triggering this function could be seen as a completely appropriate workflow.

setByfrostNetwork(uint256,uint256,addres.details: Set by the owner, this functions sets it such that this contract was deployed on a Byfrost arm of the Shyft Network (on Ethereum for example). With this is a token grant that this contract should make to a specific distribution contract (ie. in the case of the initial Shyft Network launch, we have a small allocation originating on the Ethereum network).

params._bip32X_type: The Bip32X type that represents the synthetic tokens that will be allocated.
params._distributionContract: The public address of the distribution contract, that the tokens are allocated for.
params._tokenAmount: The amount of tokens to be allocated.

returns.result: | 2 = set byfrost as origin    | 1 = already set byfrost origin    | 0 = not owner

setPrimaryNetwork().details: Set by the owner, this function sets it such that this contract was deployed on the primary Shyft Network. No further calls to setByfrostNetwork may be made.

returns.result: | 2 = set primary network    | 1 = already set byfrost origin    | 0 = not owner

setShyftCacheGraphAddress(address).details: Links Shyft CacheGraph to this contract's function flow.

params._shyftCacheGraphAddress: The smart contract address for the Shyft CacheGraph that should be linked.

returns.result: | 0: not owner    | 1: set shyft cache graph address

tokenFallback(address,uint256,bytes).details: Standard ERC223 function that will handle incoming token transfers.

kycSend(address,uint256,uint256,bool,boo.notice: | If the recipient has flags set to indicate that they *only* want to receive assets from kyc sources, *all* of the regular transfer functions will block except this one, and this one only passes on success.

setByfrostNetwork(uint256,uint256,addres.notice: | for created kyc contracts on other chains, they can be instantiated with specific bip32X_type amounts         | (for example, the shyft distribution contract on eth vs. shyft native)         |  '  uint256 bip32X_type = uint256(keccak256(abi.encodePacked(nativeBip32X_type, _erc20ContractAddress)));         |  '  bip32X_type = uint256(keccak256(abi.encodePacked(nativeBip32X_type, msg.sender)));         | the bip32X_type is formed by the hash of the native bip32x type (which is unique per-platform, as it depends on         | the deployed contract address) - byfrost only touches non-replay networks.         | so the formula for the bip32X_type would be HASH [ byfrost main chain bip32X_type ] & [ byfrost main chain kyc contract address ]         | these minted tokens are given to the distribution contract for further distribution. This is all this contract         | needs to know about the distribution contract.
